title: How to Get a Few Drops from a Lemon

steps.headline: Find a suitable tool and clean it.
steps.description: The ideal tools include a knitting needle or a skewer. Give the tool a good hot wash and dry it, so that it is sterilized.

steps.headline: Place the lemon on a firm surface.
steps.description: You will want it to sit so that it cannot roll.

steps.headline: Pierce the lemon with the skewer or knitting needle.
Take the lemon and hold the hole over the bowl or saucepan and squeeze out a few drops.
Return the rest of the lemon to the fridge.
steps.description: Wrap it in foil first. It will stay fresh in there until needed again. Obviously, use it within a short space of time to prevent it from going moldy or drying out.

steps.headline: Pierce the skin of the lemon with a cocktail stick or toothpick.
Plug the hole with the cocktail stick or toothpick and refrigerate.

text: Steps Find a suitable tool and clean it. The ideal tools include a knitting needle or a skewer. Give the tool a good hot wash and dry it, so that it is sterilized. Place the lemon on a firm surface. You will want it to sit so that it cannot roll. Pierce the lemon with the skewer or knitting needle. Just make a small hole. Take the lemon and hold the hole over the bowl or saucepan and squeeze out a few drops.  Return the rest of the lemon to the fridge. Wrap it in foil first. It will stay fresh in there until needed again. Obviously, use it within a short space of time to prevent it from going moldy or drying out. Cocktail Stick or Toothpick Method Pierce the skin of the lemon with a cocktail stick or toothpick.  Squeeze out the juice needed.  Plug the hole with the cocktail stick or toothpick and refrigerate.
